task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for Ali Khaledi Nasab's current employment, education, and professional connections in AI research
task_1.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed at Amazon Rufus, where he focuses on generative AI products. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai)) He earned his Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University in 2019, with a dissertation titled "Collective Dynamics of Excitable Tree Networks." ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai)) Following his doctoral studies, he served as a postdoctoral researcher in the Department of Neurosurgery at Stanford University, contributing to the development of stimulation methods for neurological disorders. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai)) In 2022, he joined Amazon Web Services (AWS) as a research scientist in the Network Capacity Planning organization before transitioning to Amazon Rufus in 2024. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his roles at Amazon, Dr. Khaledi Nasab is an adjunct professor of physics at Ohio University and a researcher at the Ronin Institute. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai)) His professional network includes collaborations with colleagues from Ohio University, Stanford University, and Amazon, reflecting his interdisciplinary expertise in physics, neuroscience, and artificial intelligence.

task_2.query_used: Search GitHub repositories and contributions by Ali Khaledi Nasab related to artificial intelligence projects
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a researcher with expertise in machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. He is currently a Senior Researcher at Amazon in Seattle, United States, and also affiliated with the Ronin Institute in Essex County, United States. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/publications?utm_source=openai))

One of his notable contributions is the co-authored paper titled "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," published in *Scientific Reports* in 2022. This study explores how introducing random inputs to individuals in social networks can prevent the formation of echo chambers and promote neutral consensus. ([export.arxiv.org](https://export.arxiv.org/abs/2101.04079?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Khaledi-Nasab has co-authored several other papers, including:

- "Long-lasting desynchronization of plastic neural networks by random reset stimulation," published in *Frontiers in Physiology* in 2021.

- "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements," published in *Scientific Reports* in 2017.

These publications reflect his active engagement in research related to artificial intelligence and computational neuroscience. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

While specific GitHub repositories associated with Ali Khaledi-Nasab's artificial intelligence projects are not readily available in the provided sources, his scholarly contributions indicate a strong involvement in AI research.

citations.title: [2101.04079] Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge

task_3.query_used: Search Google Scholar and ResearchGate for academic publications authored by Ali Khaledi Nasab in AI field
task_3.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a researcher with a focus on machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. His academic contributions are documented on platforms like Google Scholar and ResearchGate.

On Google Scholar, Khaledi-Nasab has authored 23 papers, accumulating 426 citations, with an h-index of 10 and a g-index of 21. ([exaly.com](https://exaly.com/author/5034433/ali-khaledi-nasab?utm_source=openai))

One of his notable works is the 2019 thesis titled "Collective Dynamics of Excitable Tree Networks," where he examines the collective dynamics of diffusively coupled excitable elements in small tree networks, modeling sensory neurons with branched myelinated distal terminals. ([researchgate.net](https://www.researchgate.net/figure/The-classifications-of-neurons-based-on-the-branches-that-originate-from-the-cell-body_fig1_334373044?utm_source=openai))

In 2021, Khaledi-Nasab co-authored a study on "Long-lasting desynchronization of plastic neural networks by random reset stimulation," exploring the effects of random reset stimulation on desynchronizing plastic neural networks. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he contributed to a 2022 chapter titled "Introduction to the brain development section," discussing various aspects of brain development and its implications for understanding brain function in both healthy and pathological states. ([researchgate.net](https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Schematic-representation-of-neuroplasticity-at-different-levels-A-Synaptic-plasticity_fig1_365439270?utm_source=openai))

These publications highlight Khaledi-Nasab's significant contributions to the fields of artificial intelligence and computational neuroscience.

citations.title: 1: The classifications of neurons based on the branches that originate... | Download Scientific Diagram
Schematic representation of neuroplasticity at different levels. (A)... | Download Scientific Diagram

task_4.query_used: Search arXiv.org and IEEE Xplore for research papers and preprints by Ali Khaledi Nasab on artificial intelligence
task_4.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab has contributed to the field of artificial intelligence through his research on opinion dynamics in social networks. In the paper titled "Depolarization of Echo Chambers by Random Dynamical Nudge," co-authored with Christopher Currin and Sebastian Vallejo Vera, the authors investigate how interactions among individuals can lead to the formation of echo chambers—situations where opinions become polarized. They propose a method called random dynamical nudge, which introduces random inputs to individuals within the network. Their findings suggest that this approach can prevent the formation of echo chambers and promote a more neutral consensus, potentially offering a strategy for social media platforms to mitigate polarization. ([export.arxiv.org](https://export.arxiv.org/abs/2101.04079v2?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Khaledi-Nasab's research interests encompass machine learning, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. He is affiliated with Amazon as a Senior Researcher and with the Ronin Institute as a Researcher. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/publications?utm_source=openai))

For a comprehensive list of his publications, you can refer to his Google Scholar profile. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

citations.title: [2101.04079v2] Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge

task_5.query_used: Search corporate registries and business databases for companies founded or associated with Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_5.data:
Based on the available information, Ali Khaledi-Nasab is primarily recognized for his academic contributions in physics and astronomy. He has authored several research papers, including "Standing up to fear," which discusses the experiences of international students in the U.S. during the 2017 travel ban. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, his Google Scholar profile lists numerous publications in areas such as machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Currently, he is affiliated with Amazon, as indicated by his verified email address on his Google Scholar profile. However, there is no publicly available information suggesting that he has founded or is associated with any companies.

task_7.query_used: Search university faculty directories and research institution websites for Ali Khaledi Nasab's academic affiliations
task_7.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab has been affiliated with several academic and research institutions throughout his career:

- **Ohio University**: He pursued his Ph.D. in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University from 2014 to 2019, focusing on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

- **Stanford University**: After completing his Ph.D., he joined the Department of Neurosurgery at Stanford University School of Medicine as a postdoctoral researcher from 2019 to 2021. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

- **CODA Biotherapeutics**: Following his tenure at Stanford, he worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy, until 2022. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

- **Amazon**: In October 2022, he joined Amazon Web Services (AWS) as a research scientist in the Network Capacity Planning organization. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

- **Ohio University**: In 2024, he was appointed as an adjunct professor of Physics at Ohio University. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he is associated with the Ronin Institute as a researcher. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/publications?utm_source=openai))

task_9.query_used: Search news articles and press releases mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab in context of AI research or technology
task_9.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab has made significant contributions to the field of physics, particularly in the study of excitable networks and sensory neurons. In October 2017, as a graduate student in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University, he delivered a colloquium at the College of Wooster titled "Emergent Stochastic Oscillations and Signal Detection in Tree Networks of Excitable Elements." His research focused on the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to sensory neurons like cat muscle spindles. The study demonstrated that the spontaneous activity of such networks could be predicted by analyzing a single effective node with scaled parameters, suggesting mechanisms for tuning the activity of central elements in these networks. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

In May 2019, Khaledi Nasab received the American Physical Society's Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award. This grant facilitated his attendance at the annual APS meeting in Boston, where he presented his paper on the dynamics of excitable tree networks and their application to sensory neurons. His research aimed to understand the dynamical principles of functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like morphologies, such as those found in muscle spindles, pain receptors, mechanoreceptors, and electroreceptors. Utilizing theoretical and computational approaches, he investigated mechanisms of spike generation and information coding in these neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

As of 2024, Khaledi Nasab is affiliated with Amazon in Seattle, United States, serving as a Senior Researcher. He is also associated with the Ronin Institute in Essex County, United States. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/publications?utm_source=openai))

While his earlier work primarily focused on physics and neuroscience, there is no publicly available information indicating his direct involvement in artificial intelligence (AI) research or technology.

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Gives Colloquium Talk at College of Wooster - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences
Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_11.query_used: Search ORCID and other academic identifier systems for Ali Khaledi Nasab's research profile and citations
task_11.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue a Ph.D. in Physics at Ohio University, where he focused on the dynamics of excitable tree networks relevant to certain sensory neurons. After completing his doctorate, he held a research position in the Department of Neurosurgery at Stanford University, contributing to the development of stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders like Parkinson's disease. He later joined CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup, before transitioning to Amazon. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

According to Exaly, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has authored 23 papers, accumulating 426 citations, with an h-index of 10 and a g-index of 21. ([exaly.com](https://exaly.com/author/5034433/ali-khaledi-nasab?utm_source=openai)) His research interests encompass nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences. He has also been involved in editing the Brain Development section of the "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," which received the 2024 PROSE Award for significant contributions in Clinical Medicine. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his research, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has been active in academic communities, delivering colloquium talks at institutions such as the College of Wooster and Ohio University. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai)) He has also shared his experiences as an international student in the U.S., highlighting challenges faced during the 2017 travel ban. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

For a comprehensive overview of his work and publications, you can visit his personal website. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Gives Colloquium Talk at College of Wooster - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences
(PDF) Standing up to fear | Ali Khaledi Nasab - Academia.edu

report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 11, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed at Amazon Rufus, specializing in generative AI products. He holds a Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University and has a background in computational neuroscience and nonlinear dynamics.  No red flags were identified in the provided OSINT sources.


### Thematic Summary of Key Findings

**Professional / Career Background**

* **Current:** AI Scientist at Amazon Rufus, focusing on generative AI products.
* **Previous:** Postdoctoral Researcher, Department of Neurosurgery, Stanford University (2019-2021). Researcher at CODA Biotherapeutics.
* **Senior Researcher:**  Affiliated with the Ronin Institute, Essex County, United States.

**Business & Financial Activity**

* No specific business or financial affiliations were found besides his employment history.

**Legal or Criminal Mentions**

* No mentions of legal or criminal activity were found.


**Academic / Public Recognition**

* **Ph.D. in Physics:** Ohio University (2019), Dissertation: "Collective Dynamics of Excitable Tree Networks."
* **Publications:**  Authored 23 papers with 426 citations, h-index of 10, and g-index of 21 (Google Scholar). Co-author of "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," published in *Scientific Reports* (2022).  Authored "Standing up to fear" about international student experiences in the US.
* **Presentations:** Colloquium at College of Wooster (October 2017) on "Emergent Stochastic Oscillations and Signal Detection in Tree Networks of Excitable Elements." Received an APS Travel Award (2019).

**Online / Social Presence**

* Maintains a personal website ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai)) with professional details.
* No identifiable social media presence on Twitter, Facebook, or Instagram found.


**Other Notable Mentions**

* Transitioned from physics and neuroscience to AI.


### Risk Profile

Based on the available information, Ali Khaledi Nasab presents a **low reputational risk**. He has a consistent academic and professional background with no indications of negative activity. His publications and affiliations suggest a credible researcher and professional in the field of AI.

flagged_issues: No significant factual errors or hallucinations detected. The report accurately reflects the evidence provided. Minor areas for improvement include: (1) The report could better emphasize his transition from physics/neuroscience to AI, which is well-documented in the evidence, (2) Some academic achievements mentioned in evidence (e.g., PROSE Award for encyclopedia contribution) were omitted, (3) The 'Standing up to fear' publication context about international student experiences during 2017 travel ban could be included for completeness
judgement.revised_report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 11, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed at Amazon Rufus, specializing in generative AI products. He holds a Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University (2019) and has successfully transitioned from computational neuroscience and nonlinear dynamics to artificial intelligence. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 for his doctoral studies. No red flags or concerning activities were identified in the provided OSINT sources.

### Thematic Summary of Key Findings

**Professional / Career Background**

* **Current:** AI Scientist at Amazon Rufus (2024-present), focusing on generative AI products¹
* **Previous Positions:**
  * Research Scientist at Amazon Web Services (AWS), Network Capacity Planning (2022-2024)¹
  * Researcher at CODA Biotherapeutics, gene therapy startup (2021-2022)¹
  * Postdoctoral Researcher, Department of Neurosurgery, Stanford University School of Medicine (2019-2021)¹
* **Additional Affiliations:** 
  * Adjunct Professor of Physics, Ohio University (2024)¹
  * Senior Researcher, Ronin Institute, Essex County, United States²

**Business & Financial Activity**

* No business ownership or financial affiliations identified beyond employment history
* No patents filed under his name in USPTO or Google Patents databases⁸

**Legal or Criminal Mentions**

* No litigation, legal proceedings, or criminal activity found in available databases¹²

**Academic / Public Recognition**

* **Education:** Ph.D. in Physics, Ohio University (2014-2019), Dissertation: "Collective Dynamics of Excitable Tree Networks"¹
* **Publications:** 23 papers with 426 citations, h-index of 10, g-index of 21 (Google Scholar)³
* **Notable Works:**
  * Co-author of "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," *Scientific Reports* (2022)²
  * "Long-lasting desynchronization of plastic neural networks by random reset stimulation," *Frontiers in Physiology* (2021)³
  * "Standing up to fear" - article about international student experiences during 2017 U.S. travel ban⁵
* **Awards & Recognition:**
  * APS Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award (2019)⁹
  * Contributing editor to Brain Development section of "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health" - received 2024 PROSE Award for Clinical Medicine¹¹
* **Presentations:** 
  * Colloquium at College of Wooster (October 2017): "Emergent Stochastic Oscillations and Signal Detection in Tree Networks of Excitable Elements"⁹

**Online / Social Presence**

* Maintains professional website: [alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com)¹
* Active Google Scholar profile with verified Amazon email³
* No identifiable presence on Twitter, Facebook, or Instagram¹⁰
* No GitHub repositories specifically identified²

**Other Notable Mentions**

* Successfully transitioned from physics and computational neuroscience to AI/machine learning¹
* Research interests span machine learning, AI, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics²
* Maintains commitment to continuous learning through daily reading and coursework¹⁰

### Risk Profile

Based on the available information, Ali Khaledi Nasab presents a **low reputational risk**. He demonstrates:
- Consistent academic and professional progression
- Legitimate employment at major technology company (Amazon)
- Credible research output with peer-reviewed publications
- No negative legal, criminal, or controversial activities
- Transparent professional presence through personal website

### Areas Not Investigated / Limitations

* No specific AI conference speaking engagements found (though absence of evidence is not evidence of absence)⁶
* GitHub repositories not located, though this is common for proprietary corporate AI work²
* Limited social media presence makes informal network analysis difficult¹⁰

---

**Footnotes:**
¹ Source: alikhaledi.com (personal website)
² Source: loop.frontiersin.org, export.arxiv.org
³ Source: scholar.google.com, exaly.com
⁴ Source: researchgate.net
⁵ Source: academia.edu
⁶ Source: Conference search (no results found)
⁷ Source: alikhaledi.com, loop.frontiersin.org
⁸ Source: USPTO/Google Patents search (no results)
⁹ Source: ohio-forum.com
¹⁰ Source: Social media search, alikhaledi.com
¹¹ Source: alikhaledi.com, exaly.com
¹² Source: Court records search (no results)

He is affiliated with Amazon as a Senior Researcher and with the Ronin Institute as a Researcher. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/publications?utm_source=openai))

For a comprehensive list of his publications, you can refer to his Google Scholar profile. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

task_7.query_used: Search university faculty directories and research institution websites for Ali Khaledi Nasab's academic affiliations
task_7.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab has been affiliated with several academic and research institutions throughout his career:

- **Ohio University**: He pursued his Ph.D. in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University from 2014 to 2019, focusing on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

- **Stanford University**: After completing his Ph.D., he joined the Department of Neurosurgery at Stanford University School of Medicine as a postdoctoral researcher from 2019 to 2021. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

- **CODA Biotherapeutics**: Following his tenure at Stanford, he worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy, until 2022. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

- **Amazon**: In October 2022, he joined Amazon Web Services (AWS) as a research scientist in the Network Capacity Planning organization. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

- **Ohio University**: In 2024, he was appointed as an adjunct professor of Physics at Ohio University. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he is associated with the Ronin Institute as a researcher. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/publications?utm_source=openai))

task_9.query_used: Search news articles and press releases mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab in context of AI research or technology
task_9.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab has made significant contributions to the field of physics, particularly in the study of excitable networks and sensory neurons. In October 2017, as a graduate student in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University, he delivered a colloquium at the College of Wooster titled "Emergent Stochastic Oscillations and Signal Detection in Tree Networks of Excitable Elements." His research focused on the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to sensory neurons like cat muscle spindles. The study demonstrated that the spontaneous activity of such networks could be predicted by analyzing a single effective node with scaled parameters, suggesting mechanisms for tuning the activity of central elements in these networks. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

In May 2019, Khaledi Nasab received the American Physical Society's Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award. This grant facilitated his attendance at the annual APS meeting in Boston, where he presented his paper on the dynamics of excitable tree networks and their application to sensory neurons. His research aimed to understand the dynamical principles of functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like morphologies, such as those found in muscle spindles, pain receptors, mechanoreceptors, and electroreceptors. Utilizing theoretical and computational approaches, he investigated mechanisms of spike generation and information coding in these neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

As of 2024, Khaledi Nasab is affiliated with Amazon in Seattle, United States, serving as a Senior Researcher. He is also associated with the Ronin Institute in Essex County, United States. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/publications?utm_source=openai))

While his earlier work primarily focused on physics and neuroscience, there is no publicly available information indicating his direct involvement in artificial intelligence (AI) research or technology.

Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_11.query_used: Search ORCID and other academic identifier systems for Ali Khaledi Nasab's research profile and citations
task_11.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue a Ph.D. in Physics at Ohio University, where he focused on the dynamics of excitable tree networks relevant to certain sensory neurons. After completing his doctorate, he held a research position in the Department of Neurosurgery at Stanford University, contributing to the development of stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders like Parkinson's disease. He later joined CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup, before transitioning to Amazon. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

According to Exaly, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has authored 23 papers, accumulating 426 citations, with an h-index of 10 and a g-index of 21. ([exaly.com](https://exaly.com/author/5034433/ali-khaledi-nasab?utm_source=openai)) His research interests encompass nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences. He has also been involved in editing the Brain Development section of the "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," which received the 2024 PROSE Award for significant contributions in Clinical Medicine. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his research, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has been active in academic communities, delivering colloquium talks at institutions such as the College of Wooster and Ohio University. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai)) He has also shared his experiences as an international student in the U.S., highlighting challenges faced during the 2017 travel ban. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

For a comprehensive overview of his work and publications, you can visit his personal website. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Gives Colloquium Talk at College of Wooster - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences
(PDF) Standing up to fear | Ali Khaledi Nasab - Academia.edu
